title: Interviews Guidelines
overview: At the start of your project, youâ€™ll interview users or clients to capture functional requirements. Listen also for hidden priorities â€” trade-offs, long-term impacts, and values â€” that can spark conversation about sustainability.
purpose: Use interviews to gather functional needs from users and clients while subtly introducing sustainability as a background theme. Pay attention to values, trade-offs, and hidden priorities to capture early signals if sustainability might become a requirement.

steps.title: Set the Goal
steps.description: Decide what you want to learn from the interview â€” e.g., clarifying requirements, understanding context, or exploring priorities.

steps.title: Choose Participants
steps.description: Pick the right people to talk to. Remember: a client (who requests or funds the project) is different from a user (who actually interacts with the system).

steps.title: Prepare Questions
steps.description: Use the template to draft your interview guide. Focus on functional needs, and think about where you could also bring in sustainability â€” for example, by asking about resources, long-term effects, or excluded groups.

steps.title: Run the Interview
steps.description: Follow your guide, listen actively, and take notes directly in the template. Let sustainability come up naturally as part of the conversation.

steps.title: Summarize Insights
steps.description: Review your notes in the template. Capture functional requirements and highlight any signals of sustainability priorities, trade-offs, or hidden impacts.

input: Clear problem or project area to discuss.
Basic awareness of social or environmental sustainability.
outputs: Notes on values, trade-offs, and hidden priorities.
prompts: Suggest interview questions that help me capture core client priorities and functional requirements for [system/product].
Generate follow-up probes I can use to clarify user needs, goals, and pain points during an interview.
List subtle ways to ask about long-term impacts or resource trade-offs (time, money, energy) without directly using the word 'sustainability.'
Rewrite my interview guide so sustainability is woven naturally into functional questions instead of being a separate section.
tips: Focus on functional needs first â€” let sustainability emerge in the background.
Use neutral language like resources, impacts, or long-term effects instead of repeating 'sustainability.'
Listen for hints about costs, effort, or risks â€” these often signal hidden trade-offs.
After the interview, review with your team whether any insights point to sustainability as a potential requirement.

title: Stakeholder Impact Mapping
overview: Stakeholder mapping helps you see who is connected to your system â€” not just the obvious users, but also indirect, invisible, and even non-human actors. It asks: Whoâ€™s included? Whoâ€™s excluded? Who benefits, and who bears the costs?
purpose: Identify all relevant stakeholders, not just direct users.
Include indirect, marginalized, and non-human actors.
Surface who is excluded, who benefits, and who is most vulnerable.
Encourage ethical and systemic awareness in design decisions.

steps.title: Put the System in the Center
steps.description: Write the name of your software or concept at the heart of the map.

steps.title: List Direct Stakeholders
steps.description: Add the main users and organizations that interact with it daily.

steps.title: Add Indirect Stakeholders
steps.description: Think about regulators, suppliers, communities, or other actors affected indirectly.

steps.title: Include Neglected or Invisible Stakeholders
steps.description: Whoâ€™s usually left out â€” marginalized groups, invisible workers, or future generations?

steps.title: Map Power & Impact
steps.description: Show who has influence, who benefits, and who bears risks or costs.

input: A clear idea of your problem space.
outputs: A stakeholder map (diagram, table, or sketch) showing direct, indirect, and neglected actors.
Insights into who is excluded, who benefits, and where risks or opportunities exist.
prompts: Who are the direct users of [Your System Name]?
Which organizations, governments, or institutions interact with it?
What non-human stakeholders (e.g., ecosystems, infrastructures, species) are affected?
Which marginalized or invisible groups (e.g., low-visibility workers, future generations) might be overlooked?
tips: Push yourself to think beyond obvious users â€” add invisible and non-human actors.
Map both inclusion and exclusion to raise ethical questions.
Revisit the map as your project evolves â€” it will change over time.
note: ðŸ”Ž Stakeholder mapping focuses on *who* is involved. Ecosystem mapping goes further, showing *how everything connects and interacts*.

title: Inclusive User Groups
overview: Inclusive User Groups move beyond traditional personas by making privilege and exclusion visible. Instead of designing for a 'typical user,' this tool helps compare real groups systematically to reveal overlooked needs and impacts.
purpose: Uncover diverse user groups beyond default assumptions.
Make privilege and exclusion visible in design decisions.
Highlight neglected or invisible groups and their needs.
Ensure sustainability and inclusion are considered early.

steps.title: Define User Groups
steps.description: Identify 3â€“6 specific groups. Avoid vague categories like 'diverse users' â€” be concrete. Use data or research to support your choices.

steps.title: Map Needs, Pains, Gains
steps.description: For each group, describe key needs, barriers, and benefits. Reflect on how these link to social or environmental sustainability.

steps.title: Privilege Mapping
steps.description: Place groups on a Privilege Wheel. Compare who has high privilege, who is marginalized, and who is missing.

steps.title: Matrix Evaluation
steps.description: Use a matrix to compare groups across privilege and exclusion. Look for blank spaces or weak evidence.

steps.title: Reflect & Adjust
steps.description: Ask: Who is excluded? Whose voices are missing? Adjust, merge, or add groups to close gaps.

input: Project scope and an early idea of the target system.
Any demographic or usage data (research, reports, surveys).
Willingness to challenge assumptions and identify gaps.
outputs: Profiles of Inclusive User Groups (structured summaries, not personas).
Privilege Wheel analysis showing privilege gaps.
Reflection notes on missing perspectives and next steps.
prompts: What user groups could interact with [system/product]?
Which marginalized or overlooked groups might be affected directly or indirectly?
What needs, barriers, or benefits might [user group] face?
How do these connect to social or environmental sustainability?
Which groups are overrepresented in design decisions? Which are underrepresented?
If only privileged groups are considered, what risks or exclusions might occur?
tips: Be specific â€” generic labels hide real perspectives.
Balance human needs with social and environmental impacts.
Use privilege mapping explicitly â€” donâ€™t assume equity is automatic.
Iterate as new research emerges â€” groups may need refining.

title: Systemic Journey Map
overview: The Systemic Journey Map is like a classic UX journey map, but zoomed out. Instead of only showing the â€˜happy pathâ€™ of one user, it explores how different people, communities, and even the planet are affected along the way.
purpose: Look beyond individual user journeys and consider the bigger picture.
Show how different groups experience the system over time, including their goals, struggles, and wins.
Make visible the social and environmental effects that happen alongside the user experience.
Spot opportunities, risks, and blind spots so designs can be more inclusive and sustainable.

steps.title: Define Phases
steps.description: Break the journey into real-life stages that make sense for your chosen group.

steps.title: Core Activities
steps.description: List what this group is actually doing in each phase.

steps.title: Goals & Jobs-to-be-Done
steps.description: Ask: what is the group trying to achieve, solve, or move forward?

steps.title: Needs, Pains, Gains
steps.description: Note down detailed needs, frustrations, and benefits for the group.

steps.title: Touchpoints
steps.description: Identify where and how the group connects with the product, service, or system (digital or physical).

steps.title: Social Impacts
steps.description: Think about inequality, accessibility, inclusion/exclusion, and labor conditions that can show up.

steps.title: Environmental Impacts
steps.description: Consider energy use, waste, travel, or resource consumption connected to this step.

input: A chosen user group (from your Inclusive User Groups exercise)
Broad needs, pains, and gains (from earlier exercises)
Your initial understanding of the system or context
outputs: A journey map that includes phases, activities, goals, needs/pains/gains, touchpoints, and impacts.
A reflection on privilege, access, and exclusion in the journey.
A list of opportunities and risks for designing more sustainably and inclusively.
prompts: Suggest meaningful phases of the journey for [user group] interacting with [system/product] in [domain].
What actions or activities does [user group] typically perform in [phase]?
What specific needs, frustrations, and benefits does [user group] experience in [phase]?
How might these differ from more privileged groups in the same phase?
What social impacts (e.g., inequality, access, labor) might occur in [phase] for [user group]?
What environmental impacts (e.g., energy, waste, travel, resource use) might occur in [phase]?
Give concrete examples of sustainability impacts for similar systems in [domain].
tips: Ground your phases in real experiencesâ€”donâ€™t just use marketing funnel stages.
Always pair UX observations with notes on social or environmental impacts.
Use insights from Inclusive User Groups and Stakeholder Mapping to double-check your phases and impacts.
Remember: Inclusive User Groups give a broad overview, while the Systemic Journey Map digs deep, phase by phase.

title: Conscious Requirements
overview: Designing sustainably often means negotiating between user needs, cost, convenience, performance, accessibility, and environmental/social impacts. The Trade-offs Matrix makes these tensions visible, so teams can reflect: what are we optimizing, and at what cost?
purpose: To help students see, compare, and balance decisions where sustainability objectives conflict with other design or business priorities. It supports conscious trade-offs instead of hidden compromises.

steps.title: List Options
steps.description: Identify 2â€“4 design or system options youâ€™re deciding between.

steps.title: Capture Benefits
steps.description: List benefits for users, business, or functionality.

steps.title: Capture Sustainability Signals
steps.description: Identify sustainability benefits (reduced energy use, improved equity, community benefit) and sustainability costs (higher resource load, exclusion risks, long-term harm).

steps.title: Capture Other Costs
steps.description: Note usability, time, money, technical debt, or short-term barriers for each option.

steps.title: Compare & Reflect
steps.description: Ask: Where do sustainability goals align or conflict with other goals? Who wins and who loses with each choice?

steps.title: Decide & Document
steps.description: Make an explicit decision and record the rationale: Why did we prioritize X over Y?

input: Clarity on what decision is being made (e.g., which feature to build, which technology to use)
outputs: A completed Trade-offs Matrix for each key decision
A record of rationale (so compromises are transparent)
Insights into decision patterns (e.g., 'We consistently deprioritize low-bandwidth users â€” should we change that?')
templates: Matrix Table: Options | Benefits | Sustainability Benefits | Sustainability Costs | Other Costs | Notes
Decision Flow Diagram: optional visualization of how each option impacts users and sustainability
prompts: List sustainability benefits and costs of choosing [design option A] over [option B].
Who benefits most and who loses out if we prioritize speed over sustainability in [system/product]?
What are short-term vs. long-term consequences of [decision] for social and environmental impacts?
Suggest ways to balance usability with sustainability in [feature/system].
tips: Avoid treating sustainability as an afterthought â€” place it alongside usability, cost, and performance.
Document trade-offs explicitly so future teams understand the rationale.
Look for patterns in decisions over time (e.g., which groups or sustainability goals are consistently deprioritized).
Revisit earlier Inclusive User Groups and Systemic Journey Maps to ground trade-off reflections in real impacts.

title: Prototyping Guidelines
overview: Prototypes are quick ways to try out ideas before building. They can be super simple or more polished. At any level, itâ€™s important to check for sustainability and inclusivity earlyâ€”so design problems donâ€™t get locked in too soon.
purpose: To make early versions of ideas that are lightweight, inclusive, and mindful of sustainability. Prototypes are not final products â€” theyâ€™re tools for exploring design choices and showing how sustainability fits in before anything is built.

steps.title: Set the Prototype Goal
steps.description: Be clear about what you want to test or visualize.

steps.title: Pick the Fidelity
steps.description: Decide if you need a Lo-Fi prototype or a Hi-Fi prototype (detailed, interactive, refining specifics).

steps.title: Build with Sustainability in Mind
steps.description: Think about whether people with different needs and contexts could actually use it.

input: Decide what youâ€™re prototyping (a flow, feature, journey step, or system effect).
Choose fidelity (quick sketch vs. Figma mockup).
Pick the user group(s) youâ€™re designing for.
outputs: A low-fi or hi-fi prototype with sustainability notes added.
Clear spots where inclusivity or sustainability might be challenged.
prompts: What are some low-fi ways to show [feature/flow] without coding?
How could I adapt this prototype for [constraint: e.g., low bandwidth / older devices]?
Where in this flow might resource use or accessibility barriers appear?
tips: Start with quick, disposable prototypes to explore lots of ideas before refining.
Prototype for marginalized or constrained groups firstâ€”not just the majority.
